history.content:
I also bombed 70 and actually did ok in 170. Ive heard this is somewhat common -- the things taught in 170 aren't really built on the concepts in 70 other than proof techniques and some general probability. Also, 170 isn't a weeder course in the same way that 70 is so there isn't as much information crammed into the semester. I found that this was probably the biggest reason I did better in 170; 70 stressed me out more than any class I have taken just because there was so much content. I felt that 170 offered a lot more breathing room so that you can really take the time to understand each topic to a greater degree.

------

Graph theory and proof by induction are two topics that will definitely appear in 170.

Also modular arithmetics and a little bit counting, depending on your semester.
-------
I found that 61B was far more useful material to have mastered than 70, but YMMV

I felt that 170 offered a lot more breathing room so that you can really take the time to understand each topic to a greater degree.

I just took 70 last semester and did pretty awful. I've taken plenty of proofy math classes in the past so I feel fine with that kind of thinking, but in terms of actual content I'm not at all competent with solving harder discrete problems. Will this be a problem taking 170? Or will 170 also teach the requisite 70 knowledge as the semester goes?
history.subject: How well do we need to know 70 material to do well in 170?
